DWYW

Cycles

Felix Deiters

The way we build is a major driver of the climate crisis. This realisation has spawned the creation of sophisticated tools to quantify the impact of the built environment on our habitat. Yet, the emergence of these frameworks does not seem to have had a meaningful impact on the paradigms of the architecture that goes up around us every day. These buildings still seem to air a mournful longing for an ill-conceived Modernism when the challenges of the present call for new approaches. Why does this disconnect exist?

I think that instruments such as Life-Cycle Assessments fail to make their mark mainly because (a) they enter the picture too late in the design process, and (b) they are fundamentally unsuccessful in communicating their results to designers.

This work argues for a new kind of material intuition and prototypes a possible vector to aid its development.

1

It's been almost ten years since I started studying and working in architecture. This was to be my last studio before beginning work on my master's thesis. Like for many of my peers, the looming climate crisis had been growing to take a bigger part of my daily life. I would spend Fridays on the streets protesting, but when I went back into the office on Monday, I was back to drawing plans for buildings that would propel the climate crisis even further. Yet, when I would try to talk my bosses and colleagues out of yet another concrete box, I would find myself fumbling.

I had hunches and notions. But they didn't add up. Were there such things as carbon-negative materials? Did they even matter? How did the impact of construction compare to the use of a building? What did the word sustainable even mean for architecture? I could not finish my education like this.

So I tried to find some answers. I joined Architects for Future, found peers to start FAQ concrete, an interest group at the UdK architecture department, and tried my hand at a systematic read-up.

Photo by Kristi McCluer
2

Let's start with some words on scope. The mess we find ourselves in touches more than just the emission of greenhouse gases. The transition to a sustainable practice of building requires a massive shift in many areas at once. Equity, justice, resilience, culture change, etc., are interrelated sides to our same figurative sustainability coin.

As architects, we tend to brush away the nitty-gritty in favour of big picture ideas. But dreaming up new futures1 doesn't absolve us from dealing with the here and now. Every artefact, a desk, a chair, or the Floating University Berlin is embedded in and product of a system. Its physical existence in the world is manifested in tangible amounts of carbon that were put into the atmosphere when it's constituent elements were manufactured.2 A fundamental opposition to these constituent realities, however uncomfortable, does not absolve us from our responsibility to navigate them. Especially when doing harm is easy and doing good is relatively difficult.

  1. A practice now more necessary than ever!
  2. See An Understanding for the Replenishment of Ecosystems
3

Before we can dive into the aforementioned nitty-gritty, we'll need to lay some more groundwork.

So, how screwed are we? These numbers are from a lecture at ETH's Block Research Group. I added the current global temperature projection for context. The full text of The Limits to Growth is available here. As far as I know, the slides are not available online, but they provide the following sources:

  • 2018 Global Status Report
  • Chatham House
  • Construction Dive
  • World Energy Outlook 2019
4

Let's back up a little more. For too long, humans have relied on a linear economic model, one that is fundamentally extractivist. Raw materials are mined and refined only to be put in landfills at the end of a product's life. All this using the energy from burning fossil fuels, releasing carbon that had been stored in the ground for hundreds of millions of years into the atmosphere. This is fundamentally incompatible with a finite system such as our planet.

5

In contrast, a circular framework takes insights from living systems. It conceives the production, use, and decomposition of goods as cycles of nutrients, matter, and energy in a closed loop. The tighter the loop, the less energy needs to be expended. We can thus read the diagram as a cascade of priorities:

  1. Do we need it at all? (In German)
  2. What is already there?
  3. Can we make something new out of something old? And only then:
  4. How can we borrow something so that it can be looped back again?

We're all well familiar with the three R's. But what if none of them apply? In the following, we'll focus on the instances when producing something new is indispensable.

6

Life-cycle assessments are a methodology to assess and quantify the environmental impact of products, processes, and services. The life-cycle of an artefact is divided into discrete stages that can be modelled with inputs and outputs of different dimensions within a system boundary. The diagram above shows these stages in relation to architecture.

It's important to note that this framework is to be understood as an attempt. Due to the complex nature of production and sourcing, with their multitude of variables, they can never produce definitive results. They can not, for instance, capture aspects that not or not easily quantifiable, as many social aspects are. But they do provide a valuable comparative heuristic, as long as the individual subjects are sufficiently consistently modelled.

7

Life-cycle information on products is compiled into so-called Environmental Product Declarations or EPDs. The individual stages of a life-cycle are modelled in flows. Shown above is the flow of the production of laminated veneer board.

The German Federal Ministry of the Interior, Building and Community maintains a fairly comprehensive database of building materials and products, called Ökobaudat.

8

Ökobaudat's EPDs necessarily cover a wide range of inputs and outputs. Unfortunately, this thoroughness also renders them virtually useless for architects and designers. Indicators such as Acidification potential, Eutrophication potential, or Abiotic depletion potential for non-fossil resources hardly provide actionable information.

The Global Warming Potential or GWP of a product or process is quantified as a multiple of the heat that would be absorbed by the same mass of carbon dioxide. So 1 kg of Carbon Dioxide has a GWP of 1, while 1 kg of Methane has a GWP of 56 – 92. (Over 20 years).

The other big issue with these quantification methodologies is that they are introduced too late in the design process. To produce reasonably accurate results, instruments such as life-cycle assessments rely on detailed modelling of the proposed artefact. Most design decisions are locked in at that point. The decisions are made much earlier in the process – and often times unconsciously.

9

A circular mode of production implies that we don't consume more than what our habitats provide us with. We must therefore also introduce the concept of time. Human cultures have long reflected the temporalities of the cycles they were embedded in. Examples of this in Europe are harvest festivals or the celebration of Midsummer.

  1. Strictly speaking, even the notion of replenishment is a problematic one. It is a mindset of extraction and scarcity (see Planetary Boundaries).
  2. As in: regain awareness of our embeddedness. We were always part.
10

From the moment we pick up a pencil, we make decisions. We draw on implicit knowledge, intuition. Early decisions, such as the organisation of a storey, have implications for the supporting structure and thus for the materials that can be used. This is where we have to start.

11

Architecture is inseparably linked with space. To think architectonically means to think spatially.

With time as the missing piece, we can map what we learned about life-cycle assessments back to the land and construct space as a metric to leverage our spatial intuition.

12

Such a metric is tied to the metabolism of a specific landscape. It is inherently local and specific. Our framework, therefore, requires that we establish a system boundary.

We can think of Berlin and Brandenburg as such a system. Brandenburg's forests cover more than 12.000 km2, approximately 40% of its area.

13

We can now relate the emissions caused by the production of an architectural element to the area of forest in Brandenburg that would sequester those emissions in a given timeframe. We choose one year.

(And, since this is hard science we're doing here, the area is also given in football fields!)

14
Let's do some modelling…
  • Columns
  • Beams
  • Walls
  • Windows
  • Doors
  • Slabs
  • Foundations
15

…and crunch some numbers.

16
Spreadsheets grow big fast. Luckily, the Ökobaudat is made available to download.
17
Let's bust out our trusty Grasshopper and do some parsing.
18
The result is an exploratory tool to intuitively assess and compare the environmental profile of architectural elements. I argue that in interacting with this tool, designers can develop new intuitions, implicit knowledge that is subconsciously recalled next time they pick up a pencil.
19

The tool works by tallying the amount of each material that makes up a given element and retrieving the material's GWP from the database. The glulam wall shown above is composed of:

  • Solid construction timber
  • Wood fibre board
  • Cross-laminated timber
20

So far, we have only looked at the status quo. To consider, for example, the electric energy expended in the production of a material, the corresponding EPD will use the country's electricity grid mix as an input. In Germany's case, its electricity mix is still predominantly non-renewable.

This is bound to change, albeit slowly. Can we modify our tool to depict a hypothetical future where all energy is generated from renewable sources?

Now, it's tough to make predictions, especially about the future. But we can use a flow's primary energy input for an approximation. If we relate the expended primary energy to the potential energy productivity of Brandenburg's landscapes, we can once again compare our architectural elements. This scenario does not consider biomass a renewable energy source, as its combustion would release the absorbed carbon back into the atmosphere and thus cancel out its sequestration effect. Brandenburg's potential energy productivity is there derived from how dense we can pack wind turbines.

Most industrial processes require high temperatures. We must thus account for conversion losses from electricity to heat. Common methods use electrolysis to generate hydrogen, which can then be burnt. Unfortunately, Ökobaudat's EPDs do not break down the ratio between electricity and heat, and these numbers are very hard to determine. So I had to fall back on a mix of dodgy sources and educated guesses.

Still, with fossil fuels out of the picture, we can see that processes that use less thermal energy are at an even bigger advantage over those that require high temperatures, such as the production of cement. The gap between a rammed earth wall and one made out of concrete grows even bigger.

21

This work hypothesises a vector to aid the development of a new kind of material intuition. It is, however, important to consider the limitations of this approach.

  1. This tool is a Proof-of-Concept rather than a turn-key solution. It is prototyped on top of the popular Rhino 3D CAD software. As such, its setup is rather involved and prone to bugs.
  2. Due to limitations of the underlying Ökobaudat, only the Cradle to Gate stages of elements are considered.
  3. EPDs have the status quo baked in. Hypotheses about renewable energy scenarios can only be made with the inclusion of additional data that is not readily available.

22
Appendix

LCAs are a valuable tool. Architects fancy themselves engineers, but something is lost when we communicate through numbers alone. Besides, I argue that this should not remain an experts' discourse. This concerns all of us. We need a cultural shift in what we think of as buildings. We collectively need to imagine new futures.

The construction industry is not going to change without societies creating fair and equitable rules. The figurative level playing field, but a global one.

Only an informed public can elect to implement effective and just policies. It is our job as experts to understand and communicate the challenges in our field and create an awareness and understanding of what's at stake. Tools such as the one presented in this work can aid that. The strategy of inducing implicit knowledges is therefore not limited to architects and planners. To influence the notion of a house and instil desire for a new kind of architecture means to also create the conditions for such an architecture to emerge. Public labs could serve as discursive spaces to imagine and prototype. Acting as nodes in a web of relations, they could play an important part in tackling the enormous issue that lies ahead.
